content: The role of natural gas in the U.S. economy has been a major part of the energy policy debate in Congress. Both the House and the Senate have held hearings related to natural gas, with numerous bills introduced. Natural gas is considered a potential bridge fuel to a lower-carbon economy due to its cleaner burning properties compared to coal and oil. The United States has become a leader in the shale gas revolution, with improved extraction methods significantly increasing production. Natural gas, including shale gas, has become a significant part of the energy debate in the U.S. and globally. The U.S. has led the shale gas revolution, increasing production through improved extraction methods. The country started exporting liquefied natural gas in 2016, potentially impacting the world economy. Factors like price, technology, environment, and politics will determine the future of natural gas markets. Other countries are closely monitoring the development of U.S. unconventional natural gas resources. Many countries are observing the evolution of U.S. unconventional natural gas resources. With its growing resource base and lower carbon emissions compared to other fossil fuels, natural gas is expected to have a greater role in the global energy mix. The U.S. consumed the most natural gas in 2015, with significant growth in unconventional reserves and production, particularly shale gas. This has shifted the U.S. from a net importer to a potential net exporter of natural gas. The industrial sector in the US increased its consumption of natural gas by 10% between 2010 and 2015, with a wider array of fuel and feedstock choices as the country expands its resource base. Global proved natural gas reserves have grown about 19% since 2005, with over half controlled by government-owned companies. New reserves are developed annually as existing reserves are consumed. This development raises concerns about the impact on domestic gas prices, the economy, and the environmental effects of hydraulic fracturing, including water usage, wastewater disposal, and the potential for human-caused earthquakes. Concerns include deep-well injection causing human-induced earthquakes and methane emissions from the natural gas sector. Regulations have been established to reduce emissions in the industry. The EPA established national air standards in 2012 to reduce methane and VOC emissions in the natural gas sector. The standards cover well sites, processing plants, and compressor stations. However, federal standards do not include all sources of methane. As natural gas production expands in the US, methane pollution may become a significant issue for policymakers. Almost all international natural gas trade is conducted through long-term contracts, typically lasting 20 years, whether by pipeline or LNG.
